They have also generally not provided safe means for the disposal of needles and syringes after use. Shooting galleries were unsupervised and did not offer any medical assistance to users. Advice and direction for those wanting to address their drug problems were also absent. While the objectives and potential benefits of the shooting galleries were obviously questionable, their activities should not be used as a means of dismissing the T-room trial, which is as different from these initiatives as chalk is from cheese.

On the first day of the T-room trial, six drug users were provided with clean equipment and injected themselves in the presence of a trained nurse. The rules for using the room include that users must be over 18, they must use their own drugs, they must inject only into their arms or legs, they must be long-term users and they cannot be assisted in drug taking by staff. Medical assistance and advice on getting off drugs is also available. The conditions of the T-room are clean and hygienic. Users must wipe down their table with disinfectant before and after use. Clearly, the conditions of the T-room trial could almost be described as idyllic when compared with the shooting galleries that Kings Cross has already embraced as a means of getting drug use off the streets.

There is certainly no question that drug use is already rife on the streets of Kings Cross. Suggestions that a safe injecting room might attract users to the area are laughable and naive, given the extent of the problem that already exists. In a recent interview, Reverend Ray Richmond from the Wayside Chapel described the situation in Kings Cross:

We already pick up 120 needles a day in our front garden and 20 to 30 needles a day in each of the male and female toilets. We do not permit this activity and people are regularly asked to leave from anything from about 1 week to 6 months for not paying attention to our rules. There are about 200 injecting drug users here at the Wayside Chapel every week. In the last 10 weeks, 8 have died.

Reverend Richmond and his group are now seeking to prevent some of these deaths, and their ideas have not emerged in a vacuum. There is a significant body of evidence from overseas to indicate that safe injecting rooms can prevent deaths. In Switzerland, where safe use rooms have been operating for over 10 years, not one death has occurred in supervised use situations.

A recent position paper on injecting facilities, prepared by the Australian Drug Foundation, supports Reverend Richmond's belief that the T-room could save lives. The paper points out that fatal drug overdoses will be reduced because staff are on hand to administer first aid and to call an ambulance. European experience also indicates that ambulan ces tend to arrive sooner because the locations are known and easily accessible. Indeed, the rate of fatal overdoses in the city of Frankfurt went from 150 to 30 within four years of opening injecting rooms.

The position of the Australian Drug Foundation on the provision of injecting facilities therefore lends considerable legitimacy to the aims and objectives of the T-room trial. The foundation believe there is a need to further explore the potential of such initiatives. Their position paper reveals a belief in the merit of safe injecting facilities, and their stance on the issue is summarised into these main points: that the health risks caused by injecting drug use pose a major public health problem, both to injecting drug users and to the wider community; that the use of injecting facilities presents significant potential to reduce the incidence of fatal overdose among injecting drug users and to improve their access to health services; that the use of injecting facilities presents significant potential to reduce public nuisance in areas of high injecting drug activity; and that the use of injecting facilities is specifically targeted at reducing the harm associated with injecting drug use, not at reducing levels of drug use within the community.

This strategy must be seen as only one part of a comprehensive response to drug use within our community. The ADF therefore strongly supports a properly conducted and controlled trial being undertaken in Australia to provide evidence on which to make decisions about the use of injecting facilities. While the paper makes no direct reference to the T-room trial, it obviously lends significant weight to the credibility of the concept. I believe it is particularly relevant that the ADF highlights the fact that safe injecting rooms are not the answer to Australia's drug problem—that they are merely a means of saving lives in the short term so that these people will be alive long enough to be able to make a decision to address their drug dependency over the long term. It is very difficult to rehabilitate someone who is already dead.

The position of the ADF also highlights the fact that the T-room cannot be relied upon as the only means of exploring the potential of safe injecting rooms. Governments at all levels need to get behind the idea and organise a large-scale trial if we are ever to determine the potential of such initiatives to save lives.

The ADF position paper also provides information on the success of injecting facilities in Europe. Facilities in Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands have been found to meet their two primary objectives. The first objective was to reduce the harm experienced by injecting drug users by reducing the risk of fatal overdose and to reduce the transmission of blood borne viruses. The second objective was to reduce the public nuisance of drug users injecting in public places. Clearly, overseas experience indicates that injecting rooms can have health benefits for both users and the broader community.

In a recent interview on the 7:30 Report, Dr Franz Trautmann from the Netherlands Institute of Mental Health and Addiction, was highly critical of Mr Howard's refusal to acknowledge scientific evidence from overseas. With regard to the Prime Minister's zero tolerance approach to both heroin trials and safe injecting rooms, Dr Trautmann commented:
There's a huge number of people using heroin in this country, a huge number of young people. I think it would be wise to at least try this before you make the statement that it has no real influence.
Reverend Richmond concurred with this view, stating:
We want to tell the Government to base health policies on evidence, not outdated moralistic opinion which has the appearance of being caring but rarely leads to effective action.

When churches start talking about the outdated and moralistic opinions of governments, I think there is significant cause for concern that government policies are out of touch with community values and concerns. However, the Prime Minister seems not to be swayed by either scientific evidence or public opinion. Indeed, his dogmatic adherence to the notion of zero tolerance has even led the government to hold back funding for school drug education programs that do not comply with his own narrow perspective.

A Senate committee hearing on 6 May revealed that a $7.5 million plan to warn schoolchildren of the dangers of drugs is still waiting for final approval, despite being given to Minister Kemp almost two months ago. An article in the Herald Sun on 7 May suggested that the reason for the delay could be the failure of the strategy to use the term `zero tolerance', with which Mr Howard has been so taken.

An education department bureaucrat, Ms Lois Sparkes, admitted that only $500,000 of the $2.5 million allocated to the plan for this financial year had been spent. In addition, none of the $500,000 had gone to schools; it had only paid for research and meetings of the National Advisory Committee on School Drug Education. Clearly, the Prime Minister's inane preoccupation with the notion of zero tolerance has tainted his ability to think and act in an objective fashion.

Susan Mitchell from the Australian was also highly critical of the Prime Minister's blind faith in so-called zero tolerance strategies in her article on 12 April. In the article, entitled, `One-liners are not policy—some ideas have nothing to recommend them', Ms Mitchell perceptively points out that Mr Howard `seems to have broadened the phrase to allow him to refuse to tolerate anything with which he does not agree'. Ms Mitchell goes on to say, `Simplistic approaches, inherent in catchphrases such as zero tolerance, are not only intellectually sloppy but dangerous.' I could not agree more with this conclusion, particularly now that it seems the Prime Minister is determined to ignore any evidence that contradicts his own personal opinions.

The T-room trial has sparked a flurry of letters to editors all across the country over the past few weeks. I would like to conclude this afternoon by reading one of these letters which, I believe, is useful in providing some perspective to the current debate on safe injecting rooms. This letter was printed in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 May and was written by a Canberra resident, Mr Bert Castellari. He said:

Back in the 1960s I was privileged to be involved in what was then a bold new experiment that tested community attitudes . . . it was the first drop-in centre at the Wayside Chapel, run by the late Rev Ted Noffs.

It provided a friendly and caring environment where young people with drug and social problems could come without fear of retribution. In those days the drugs were marijuana and LSD and the chapel guided many young people through the most traumatic times of their lives.
Nowadays the drug is heroin and the Wayside Chapel is again testing community attitudes by providing a safe environment for users of a drug that is far more destructive than marijuana or LSD.
The chapel proved to be an innovator in the `60s and it will, I hope, again prove that understanding and compassion are better cures than punishment.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in the 1990s I hope that governments can learn this lesson, too. I would like to put on the public record my support for Reverend Richmond and his group, who have initiated this progressive step. I am sure all senators agree that we must look to a variety of solutions to address the drug problem and that the most important thing is keeping people alive.

talk.start.para: —Before I begin my contribution, let me support Senator Gibbs in her contribution and as a supporter of the Wayside Chapel from the 1960s. They have always been at the forefront of innovation, treatment and the whole business of rescue, and I think they need our support at this time. It was a good speech and I thank her for it.

speech.para: However, I want to speak about something entirely different. In this matter of public interest debate today I want to speak about the crisis in the sugar industry in Queensland, particularly in North Queensland. It is a crisis that is facing not only many producers but of course many of the towns up and down the Queensland coast that depend on the sugar industry for their economic wellbeing.

While some areas in southern Queensland have had good crops, the picture in the north is very different. The quality of cane has been affected by rain since last August, and that was followed by a particularly wet summer. The ability to harvest saleable cane has also been affected, and these conditions will have adverse implications for next seasons's plantings as well.

There may or may not be such a thing as a level playing field, but in North Queensland, either way, it is a very boggy one. After a year of gradually deteriorating prices during 1998, sugar prices have virtually collapsed. Prices have been affected by the floating and devaluation of the Brazilian currency and by reduced demand in Russia, Asia and the former Soviet Union. There has also been a shift in world production. Brazil has emerged as a massive and now very competitive supplier. This relates to their advances in the production of both alcohol and ethanol and the trend towards production on large farms owned by conglomerates. In addition, there has been a decline in the ability of Australia to rely on preferential market access to areas like Canada, Indonesia and the Middle East.

Growers who experienced below-average crops and quality in the 1998 season have barely covered production and living expenses—and some of them have not even done that. Many have already started to increase indebtedness in order to meet these costs. Highly geared enterprises will be early casualties of the slump in prices. This leads to a loss of family farms and flow-on effects in the towns that are supported by the sugar industry. As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that means towns up and down the whole of the Queensland coast.

Previously, there was a series of mechanisms to cushion the impacts of recurring low world prices. These mechanisms included controlled production, a two-pool pricing system, domestic pricing and international regulation of output. Cane farmers are dealing in what is essentially a corrupt world market. I describe it as a corrupt world market because the Australian sugar industry is now the only one operating in an environment without any of these cushioning mechanisms. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know that both the Labor Party and the Democrats tried to keep in place some of those mechanisms when the government decided to remove them. We did our best during the debate to point out what it would mean and, of course, having sown the wind, the government is reaping the whirlwind.

The Democrats have previously argued for the retention of the sugar tariff to protect the livelihoods of our sugar growers, but that argument was lost, the debate in this place was lost and we are now suffering as a result. I recognise and acknowledge the contribution made by the Member for Kennedy, Bob Katter, in the other place who, along with the Labor Party and the Democrats in this place, tried to get the government to turn around its headlong flight into deregulation. But, unfortunately, he was unable to do it and in this place we did not have the numbers.

As these supports have fallen away from the sugar industry, it has been sustained to some extent in growth and economies of scale. However, these benefits have not been evident in the wet North of Queensland. The threats to Queensland sugar producers, however, come not only from overseas or from wet seasons but from within the industry itself. The proposed cane supply agreement given to growers recently did not allow sufficient time for growers' consideration, and if that agreement is signed off and does become the basis of further pricing, it will break the nexus between cane prices and sugar prices and cause further detriment to the industry.

It is felt by some growers that such an agreement does not protect their interests; rather, it gives unfair leverage to the refining sector, just as removal of the tariff did. This comes on top of the price slump and production difficulties. I point out that, in terms of the refiners, it also gives an advantage to gigantic transnational corporations such as Coca-Cola. It is the main contributor to the Australian soft drink manufacturing peak body and was well and truly behind the push to remove the sugar tariff.

The push for this agreement comes on top of the price slump and production difficulties. There would be any number of growers prepared to back the description of the proposed cane supply agreement which I am giving, although this may not be the view of the peak body nor of the associations of refiners and millers nor of the brokers. But the grassroots point of view, and the point of view of the family farmers, is certainly that, in this instance, they are at a significant disadvantage. They feel as though they are being pressured to sign off on that agreement.

Every decade has included a period of very low international prices for sugar producers. Every period of low prices is a threat to small family production units in particular and the towns they support. But when low prices are compounded by a corrupt world market and a significant lack of leadership from the government, there is a crisis. Growers would like to put the government on notice that this crisis is developing and that, unless something is done, things will get much worse. This is certainly the message growers want me to bring to the government here in Canberra.

Let me pay tribute to some of those who have contacted me, such as the Australian Canefarmers Association, Laurie Frebrellis, from North Queensland, and Mark Hoey, another sugar grower. They are very concerned about this issue and wanted me to make these points in the Senate today. They point out that the quota system in the United States is used to regulate imports. Some kind of quota system may be needed in Australia. At least, there should be a guaranteed minimum farm gate price. Unless we can get some system such as this in place, it is impossible to see a future for the sugar industry in this country.

There is, of course, the problem of overproduction. Mr Acting Deputy President, even in your own state, now that sugar is being grown in the north, this is a big issue. Not only is there an overproduction in a global sense; it is something that Australian sugar growers themselves need to look at. There is the issue of export parity pricing, which was put in place once the sugar tariff was removed. This means that the price is set by the global market, and when that price drops to almost nothing, of course the result is disaster. Once the sugar tariff was lost, which was a component in the setting of the price in this country, the global market took over, with the result we are seeing now.

The question that sugar growers in Queensland are asking is: why should the price in the domestic market be tied to the global price? There has been no reduction in the price of sugar to consumers, despite the fact that there has been an absolutely massive drop in the price to growers. So they say that if only the price could be maintained at a reasonable level in the domestic market, that would at least give them some relief. Of course, in Queensland most growers depend more on the export market than the domestic market, but it is a point they are making.

Some of the growers have said to me that it is time for the ACCC to review the abuse of the monopoly power which is being used by sugar refiners to further depress the price which growers are receiving and also the amount of cane which is being crushed by the millers. They also raised with me the issue of representation by cane growers of their position, which they feel is not always put as clearly as it should be by the cane growers organisation. I have talked to them about this and I seek to keep a relationship going with the cane growers organisation, which is the statutory body. But, again, growers are saying to me that that representation needs to be looked at. I recognise, of course, that the voluntary organisation—the Cane Farmers Association—also has expressed these concerns.

Let me say in conclusion that whether any of these suggestions from the growers which I have put to the chamber this afternoon are final solutions or even temporary solutions, I do not know. That is a matter for further debate. But much more, and beyond any mere debate, it is certainly a matter for immediate action by this government.

talk.start.para: —Last week some senators from this chamber, whilst sitting in an estimates committee hearing, were subject to a display of bureaucratic ineptitude and ministerial neglect of absolutely incredible proportions. If it were not so serious in its implications, I might be tempted to call it a comedy of errors. I refer to the sorry story of what is coming to be known as our newest university, Greenwich University—a `fully accredited Australian university', as it claims in its 1999 prospectus. I will be seeking leave later to have a photocopy of this prospectus tabled.

speech.para: Greenwich has said that it has a perfect right to call itself an Australian university: since duly established Australian universities are self-accrediting, then Greenwich University is as good as the rest. For reasons of its own, Greenwich University is wringing the maximum propaganda value out of the fortunate situation in which it now finds itself. If you remember, Greenwich University had its origins in the United States, where most recently it was located in Hawaii but was not recognised according to the local accreditation criteria. Now, however, thanks to the generosity of the Australian government, this institution of doubtful provenance and dodgy courses has truly landed on its feet.
I will read from its current prospectus. It says:

. . . in 1998 . . . the university moved to the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth of Australia and was established as a fully accredited university pursuant to statute. The Education (Greenwich University) Regulations 1998 were passed by the Norfolk Island government of the Commonwealth of Australia . . . Australia is a leader in international education and has a long tradition of distance education. These regulations were subsequently enacted as a full act of parliament by the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island, which legislation was then formally approved by the Commonwealth of Australia, education being a joint responsibility of both governments. On Wednesday 9th December that year the Greenwich University Act 1998 received the royal assent and became law.

As you will note, the Greenwich administration has even dragged the Queen into this sorry affair. The prospectus goes on to explain that Greenwich is one of only three private and 36 public universities in Australia, all of which are established under acts of parliament. It has, it says, `acquired Australian citizenship and become part of the British Commonwealth system'.

All of this is designed to enhance its commercial position as an Internet degree mill in the unsuspecting international market. All of this is at our expense—that is, yours and mine. However, a $3 billion education export industry is based on our excellence and our well-earned international reputation for excellence. It is directly under attack by this conniving invader known as Greenwich Uni versity. We have, might I say, a cuckoo in the nest.

Who is responsible for this abomination of ornithology, this feathered freeloader? The stately emu on our coat of arms—that's who. The Commonwealth emu chose to close its eyes. Our Commonwealth guardian bird turned its back. It failed to protect us. It allowed the Greenwich cuckoo to sneak past its defences. Who was the Commonwealth emu on this occasion? Who was caught napping in their bird costume? There have actually been two culprits—two Commonwealth ministers assuming the guise of emus in my sad little scenario. The minister directly responsible for this fiasco was the minister for territories, Senator Macdonald. Minister Macdonald directed that the Greenwich University bill of Norfolk Island be assented to by that territory's Administrator in line with his power under the Norfolk Island Act 1979. In doing so, the minister for territories took advice from the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The second minister duped by the Greenwich cuckoo was the education minister, Dr Kemp. Rather than emus, perhaps we are looking at two people who were acting like galahs. Both of them failed to exercise due attention. They neglected their responsibility to uphold the integrity of the Australia education system.

We have been told by Senator Ian Macdonald, who informed a Senate estimates committee on 4 May on this matter, that Greenwich University was purely a matter for Norfolk Island and was `not a major issue'. It was `not a major issue' was the claim he made to that Senate estimates committee. `It is not necessary to undertake a detailed examination of the bona fides of this entity, this outfit,' he said. We didn't need to know whether Greenwich was fit to stand alongside our real universities in the eyes of the world. As the vice-chancellors of Australia's 38 respectable universities and all the state education ministers have now made abundantly clear, the matter of Greenwich University is a very big issue indeed. It constitutes a direct threat to Australia's international reputation.

I go back to what the Greenwich University 1999 prospectus actually says. It says that Greenwich claims to be `a global university' authorised under its Australian act of parliament to grant degrees. It claims that it `fulfils Australian accreditation requirements'. It says that Australian universities must meet no external accreditation requirements because their bona fides are clear and their reputations are protected by the application of rigorous standards and quality assurance measures. And that clearly is the case with all other universities that are currently recognised.

But what Greenwich lacks is an application to these safeguards. This is due solely to its new status which is courtesy of this Commonwealth government. Under Norfolk Island law it is as accredited as the next institution—self-accredited, of course, in the case of this particular university—but, as I say, has no real accredited status of its own to actually justify the claims it has been making.

MCEETYA, through its last meeting in Adelaide on 22-23 April, has forced Dr Kemp's hand. The state ministers right across the country have indicated they are not prepared to stand by and give this flock of galahs free rein. The federal government has been forced to institute a full-scale review of the academic and financial credentials of Greenwich University.

Minister Kemp was able to extract at that meeting a promise from the Norfolk Island officials who were present that if the review finds against Greenwich then the territory will initiate steps to rescind the Greenwich University Act provided the territory's legislature sees fit to vote to do so. With the agreement of the good citizens of Norfolk Island, the cuckoo might be ejected from the Australian nest.

The minister was pressured by those at the MCEETYA meeting to use the powers conferred upon the Norfolk Island Act to disallow the Greenwich University. The government refused to do so, refused to meet its responsibilities under that act. It could have done so and this collective error of judgment could have been corrected, but this government has refused to do that. It sought a face-saving device: this inquiry to be headed by Mr Gallagher, who is the officer directly respon sible within the Public Service for the administration of the Higher Education Division.

One would ask how appropriate it is that the officer responsible should be making an inquiry into this very bungle which I would expect he would have had a good deal to do with in his own right and, one would expect, in exercising his responsibilities, would have taken all possible steps to have prevented. What we have seen, however, is that Dr Kemp and Minister Macdonald do not want to look like a pair of galahs. I cannot see, frankly, how they are going to avoid that responsibility.

Australia does face a foreign invasion in its higher education sector. This foreign invasion has been intent on exploiting our international reputation for excellence and our particularly lax regulatory environment in higher education. They have used devices such as post office boxes, rented rooms, Australian registered companies and, of course, the Internet. Every bogus professor and their pet dog can now set up a virtual university degree mill that operates out of Australia, thanks to this government.

The so-called University of Asia, for instance, claims that its registry—that is, its postal address—is in Adelaide. This is an outfit that offers bachelor degrees through the post and the Internet for a mere $US18,000 a pop. We have the St Clements University, which is registered in the British Caribbean Territory of Turks and Caicos Islands. It operates from Australia under the guise of a registered company, and if you ring its Adelaide office you are greeted by a voice saying `Australian tertiary education services and malt whisky wholesalers.' This is a company that purports to be yet another Australian university.

The Australasian Institute is another one. It advertised, `Your MBA at the push of a button.' It claims affiliations with genuine Australian universities, which, of course, they have all denied, and has already hoodwinked at least 11 unsuspecting international students to pay thousands of up-front dollars for worthless qualifications. This outfit operates out of an office on the Gold Coast.

We talk a great deal about defence in this country, and so we ought to. We ought to also be discussing the defence of this country's international reputation in regard to its higher education. Australia's defence against these unscrupulous freeloaders is in complete disarray. The federal government has finally agreed that we need a quick response and a combined regulatory approach involving states and territories, and it is about time that occurred.

This Greenwich episode is a shameful display of this government's negligence. Let us get it right. Let us keep the invading cuckoo universities from fouling our nest in higher education. I seek leave to have this document tabled.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —At the beginning of last month, there was a story in the Australian Financial Review that carried the headline `New port rates give little joy'. The story reported on the official government waterfront productivity data. It amounted to a report card on the impact of Mr Reith's and Mr Corrigan's campaign against waterside workers on port efficiency.

speech.para: Senators would recall that it was a very extensive campaign, both in its development and its implementation, as well as in its cost. It cost taxpayers many millions of dollars directly, port users tens of millions of dollars, and the broader community probably hundreds of millions of dollars. It also created bitter social divisions. Who can forget the images of men wearing balaclavas and with dogs on chains on the waterfront?

The government data, which related to the December quarter, showed productivity had remained flat overall, with falls recorded in three of the five major ports. Sydney saw a fall of 4.9 per cent in movements per hour in the quarter, Brisbane was down 7.7 per cent in the same period, and Fremantle dropped by 6.8 per cent. Adelaide remained unchanged, but at a high rate of over 23 lifts per hour. This high rate reflects the positive relationship between workers and management at Port Adelaide. The five-port average for the quarter declined by one per cent. Naturally, I suppose, the response to these numbers from Minister Anderson, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, was to attack the MUA.

The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business said at the beginning of April last year that both the major stevedores, P&O and Patrick's, had given a written commitment to reform in line with seven objectives. The commitment was allegedly given in return for access to a $250 million loan to pay redundancies. Those benchmarks, including an end to overmanning, high productivity, greater reliability, improved safety, lower costs through the logistics chain, greater use of technology and more training, were part of the process. The loan was to be paid back by way of a levy. It was to be administered through a wholly owned Commonwealth company, MIFCo.

Mr Reith said all the costs would be met by the stevedores, not the government. He said this was a speedy process and port users would not be the ones to pay. He said he had commitments from both the major operators, who together account for about 90 per cent of the stevedoring in this country, that they would absorb the cost of the levy. He said it would not be passed on to users, and therefore ultimately the taxpayers, in the form of higher costs. He told parliament:
Both major stevedores have agreed that the levy at this rate can be absorbed into their existing structure of charges so there is no overall cost increase in costs to shippers.
He went further by suggesting that stevedoring rates would actually fall and he predicted that the waterfront would all be fixed by Christmas 1998. I will quote him again:
I said that we would fix up the waterfront by Christmas, and I am still working to that timetable.

But, in evidence to a Senate inquiry into the legislation required to set up the levy arrangements, the major stevedores had a different view. They said that their margins were thin and the added costs would be difficult to bear.

Mr Mason, P&O's general counsel, said his company had signed a statement of support for the seven government objectives. I asked Mr Mason whether P&O had given a written commitment to absorb the cost of the levy. He said no. Mr Mason said that the government target of 25 movements per hour was just a target. He pointed to the reality that some vessels are very difficult to work and may limit the crane movement to 10 movements per hour.

Mr Corrigan said Patrick's also supported, in general, the proposed reform. There was nothing in that commitment about absorbing costs. Mr Corrigan offered to give such a commitment to the committee. However, senators would be aware that Mr Corrigan is currently the subject of a Federal Police investigation into alleged false evidence he gave to the Industrial Relations Commission relating to the Dubai fiasco. Mr Corrigan also misled a number of media outlets in relation to his knowledge of the failed training exercise. So in that case his word was nothing, and that appears to be the case still.

This whole exercise—initiated by the former minister for transport, Mr Sharp, and hijacked by Mr Reith—was never about reform of the waterfront. The real objective was to beat the union—and that is a trophy Mr Reith would love to have. It is now clear that the users of the ports and, ultimately, the Australian community are the ones paying for this political indulgence.

Nor was the establishment of MIFCo to administer the levy system about assisting the reform process. It was not about increasing efficiency; it was a payback to Mr Corrigan for acting as the government's agent in campaigning against the union. It was part of an arrangement with Chris Corrigan to provide him with financial cover while he set about illegally sacking 2,000 workers. Importantly, it was also about masking Mr Corrigan's failures as a stevedore; helping to fund his corporate strategies, such as his failed and expensive attempt to grab market share from his opponent P&O; and also helping him overcome a complete lack of industrial relations skills.

Mr Corrigan's management of Patrick's led him to a position where he had to crash or crash through. While he was not initially attracted to Mr Reith's and Mr Sharp's plan, in the end that was the only option left to him. Patrick's offered Mr Reith a vehicle to attack the MUA, and Mr Reith offered Patrick's an open chequebook.

The minister for transport recently provided me with an answer to a question taken on notice about the operations of MIFCo. He said there had been 820 workers paid out. He said the companies involved were all companies associated with Chris Corrigan. Those numbers are as at 8 February. In an earlier answer I was told that, as at 14 December, five Patrick companies had received redundancy related payments since 8 April 1998. Those Patrick companies had been provided with $102 million. A second answer related to the issue of workers being given packages and then being re-employed. Funding is not available for workers who take a package on Friday and are then rehired on the Monday.

The minister told me that on 3 September the secretary to the department of workplace relations wrote to MIFCo drawing its attention to reports that Patrick's was looking to re-employ supervisors who were taking packages. Patrick's responded on the same day, denying the allegations. The Chairman of MIFCo then wrote to Patrick's on 4 September and again on 8 September on the same matter. MIFCo found it necessary to write to Patrick's twice in four days, even though Patrick's had assured MIFCo on 3 September that it was not planning to rehire any redundant workers. MIFCo felt the need to conduct a company search of Red D Hire, the company allegedly associated with the Patrick group as well. Clearly, rumours in the industry about Patrick's misusing the redundancy payments persisted. And clearly, while Mr Reith was happy for Mr Corrigan to do his dirty work, he does not trust him with the taxpayers' money—and, I must say, nor should he.

Mr Chris Corrigan, with the government cheering from the sidelines, sacked 1,400 permanent and 600 casual workers from 17 ports around the country. This was the climax of a government plan developed over a long period of time, at a cost to the taxpayer of several million dollars. The cost con tinues to grow as parties in this process continue to argue in the courts.

It was also a secret process. The government went to enormous lengths and continues to do so to prevent details of its strategy being scrutinised by the parliament and by the public. A senior officer of the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Derren Gillespie, was even prepared, it seems, to give false evidence on a number of occasions to the Senate to protect the government.

Mr Corrigan did need financial help from the government, because the plan that he was pursuing was an expensive exercise. In 1997-98 the Patrick parent company, Lang Corporation, had to pay out $58.6 million because of the dispute induced by Mr Reith. Lang also had to cover compensation claims from businesses that suffered financial loss as a result of the dispute. The shipowners' losses amounted to about $30 million, and the broader economy lost an estimated $250 million. But there was also a significant cost to the other major stevedore, P&O. That company's agreement with the MUA was put back some 12 months and the bills are still coming in.

The evidence now shows that, despite all the economic and social disruption caused by the government's plan to smash organised labour on the Australian waterfront and despite the minister's claiming that the waterfront would be fixed by last Christmas, productivity is worse—certainly no better—than it was before Mr Reith and Mr Corrigan embarked on their folly.

What about the government claim that stevedoring charges would go down and the assurance that the government gave that stevedores would absorb the cost of redundancies paid through the MIFCo levy? As I said earlier, there was no such commitment by the major stevedores, nor was there a commitment to the benchmarks contained in the seven objectives that the government attempted to link to the redundancy assistance. There was just in-principle support for the goals.

Contracts with stevedores are generally for one or two years, and a number of major contracts were renegotiated around the end of last year and early this year. Senators might recall an article on the back page of the Australian Financial Review of 6 March, saying that shipping companies had been eagerly awaiting big cuts in stevedoring rates. After all, that was what the war on the docks was all about. That is why they copped all the costs associated with the government induced industrial chaos. But rather than cutting costs, Mr Corrigan pushed for price increases of up to 22 per cent and an average increase of around 15 per cent.

I understand that, in the end, new contracts were struck at rates similar to those applying in 1998—notwithstanding the fact that there was an attempt by Mr Corrigan's companies to ratchet the rates up, certainly not down. This is sharply in contrast with promises by the government and also a view put by the National Farmers Federation, which was among the government's front-line troops in this campaign.

At the Senate inquiry into the establishment of the levy system last year, the then Deputy Director of the National Farmers Federation, James Ferguson, said Patrick's would save $50 million a year from reduced labour costs. He said some of these savings would go to paying off the levy but some would be passed on to users—his constituency, the farming community. He was dead wrong. One year on, not one cent of savings has been seen by the farmers, and they are not likely to see any benefit in the future. Nor is anyone else, except Mr Corrigan and his companies. The share price of the Lang Corporation has gone from around $1.50 during the dispute to $4.80 at close of business yesterday.

Mr Corrigan addressed an Australian Chamber of Shipping luncheon on 28 April. He told that gathering there would be no downward movement in rates until he had recovered around $70 million in costs he had incurred trying to smash the MUA. The costs of legal action currently being taken against Corrigan by Major Wells and others will also be paid by users. The fact that users and therefore consumers will have to meet all the costs incurred by Mr Corrigan through the MIFCo redundancy arrangements is a given. At current rates it will take the Lang Corporation about four or five years to get its money back.

It is not unreasonable for port users to conclude that all that industrial and financial pain was for nothing. It is also not unreasonable to conclude that this expensive and disruptive exercise has changed little. There are fewer workers on the docks than before, but those reductions were already in the pipeline.

talk.start.para: —They were, and the evidence shows it. The senator might update himself in regard to the evidence rather than interjecting so thoughtlessly.

speech.para: Work practices have also changed, but again those changes would have come about through negotiation, which was well advanced before this dispute. When I say `negotiation', I mean the approach adopted by P&O, not Chris Corrigan. Perhaps the only real change that has been achieved out of this process is that Mr Corrigan's wealth has grown.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Isn't it true that the government's offer of just $20 million for respite care assistance means that only 900 of the 13,400 families you have identified as currently in desperate need of respite care for their child with a disability will receive any assistance at all? How will the government decide which families are to receive this paltry assistance provided in the budget?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I did notice that Senator Evans was putting that stuff about in his press release. It is a pity that he did not listen to the question that I was asked by, I think, Senator Allison two or three weeks ago. He then asked almost the same question himself about a week ago. He got the same answer about unmet need that I gave the Senate at the time. The respite care measure that Senator Evans is referring to is long overdue and badly needed. It does meet an area of unmet need, that is, carers of profoundly disabled children for whom there has been little or no opportunity for respite care. Senator Evans may think it is not much to support 900 families who have been almost torn asunder by the stress of caring for children with these disabilities. I would hope that Senator Evans would recognise that people with some disabilities have greater needs than others and this is a group of families who are in particular distress with the caring needs that they have taken on their shoulders.

answer.para: In addition the budget includes a measure for carers of people suffering from dementia—they may be older people with dementia but they may not be. So there are two measures in the budget that go to supporting carers. But most important of all, as I have told the Senate twice before, at the meeting of the Commonwealth, state and territory ministers on unmet need in disabilities I committed our government to providing support to meet the unmet need bill of $294 million. None of the states were prepared to make the commitment in terms of dollars at that time and we will be meeting again in the next couple of months. Work is going on urgently, Senator, if I can convince you at last—

talk.start.para: —Two years it's taken you.

—Oh, no. For 13 years Labor was in power and could well have started preventing the unmet need let alone addressing what had already built up. It is a disgrace and it is a wonder that he can even open his mouth about the subject. We have inherited the unmet need of a couple of decades, but 13 years of that was the responsibility of the Hawke-Keating governments. We are ready to try to take our share of the responsibility. The states and territories have also said, in a joint communique, that they will share the role as well.
—The Lib ministers said you were awful.

—They did nothing of the sort. They played the usual games that states do when they are negotiating with the Commonwealth. The fact remains that we all recognise that there is a need, we agree on the quantum of the need and we have agreed to take a shared responsibility in meeting that need. The fewer political games that are played, either at the state and territory level or by the opposition, the better, because it is people with disabilities and their carers who are the losers in those games, Senator Evans.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is the carers and the people with the disabilities who are asking this question. They want to know where the money is. You have had two big budgets since the report identifying the need. You have no money in either budget to seriously address the problem. Instead the government gloats over $5.4 billion worth of surplus. What does the minister say to those 12,500 families who will not receive any assistance at all, many of whom have been contemplating giving up their children because they just cannot cope? What do you say to them?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is not only just a lot of rot that we have heard, but it is a bit rich coming from the party that produced the Commonwealth debt which we are now trying to pay off with the surplus. By paying off the Commonwealth debt as soon as we can—and that is what the surplus enables us to do—we are increasing the possibility, over the next decade, of making sure that services to all people in need can be more generously met because we are not wasting it on interest payments that go to foreign banks or anywhere else.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Opposition senators will cease interjecting.

—It is important that this country focuses on getting itself into a good economic position so it can be a more caring society. In the meantime we are prepared to meet our share of the responsibilities we inherited from Labor.

—My question without notice is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Minister, last night's federal budget has delivered on all the promises made by the Howard government in last year's election, with major spending commitments on families, the aged, health, education and rural and regional Australia. Minister, can you inform the Senate of the importance of the budget surplus to Australia's economic future and in particular for low interest rates? What further reforms can be added to this responsible management of the nation's finances to promote further economic growth and job creation?

—Rarely has a budget received such widespread acclaim as last night's Howard government budget—acclaim from the media, lobby groups, financial markets and the community. It is true that we have delivered on our election promises and we have done it without raiding the nation's Bankcard, without racking up debt the way Labor did year after year. There are a wide range of responsible spending initiatives in the areas mentioned by the honourable senator, but we have not spent money that we do not have. The budget remains in surplus. Madam President, I remind you that this year's budget is $5.4 billion in surplus—the third surplus in a row that this government has delivered. What a contrast to Labor. Remember the last five years of Labor—$80 billion of accumulated deficits.

answer.para: The budget surplus is important to Australia because it is being used wisely. It is being used to repay Labor's debt—the $80 billion of debt that the Australian people have to repay. This government, through prudent economic management, is putting the funds together to repay that debt. By doing so it is keeping the economy strong, helping to protect us from the economic turmoil that is being experienced on the part of our Asian neighbours. Most importantly, it is helping to keep interest rates down. That is good for Australian home buyers; it is also good for Australian business, particularly small business. I remind the Senate that home owners are saving about $300 a month on an average home loan because of the cuts in interest rates that have been achieved by the Howard government. Throw away the surplus, as Labor would, and you throw away the benefits of low interest rates. As the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said last night, this surplus will ensure interest rates are kept low.

The budget is also a wake-up call to the Senate. Clearing government debt and reforming the tax system are great national challenges and I would say it is time the Senate took up that challenge. We could completely wipe out Commonwealth debt by the year 2002-03 if the Senate would pass the government's legislation—both the tax reform package and the full sale of Telstra. It is as simple as that. We could clear Australian government debt for the first time in a century. At the same time we would be able to deliver $13 billion of cuts in personal income tax to Australian taxpayers.

We remember what the hapless shadow Treasurer said last night when referring to the GST. He said, `We want to hold this government to its promises.' If they want to hold the government to the promises, they will support the sale of Telstra and they will support the government in implementing its new tax system. Both proposals were put in full to the Australian people at the last election. Employer groups also want the Senate to get on with the job. Last night the Australian Industry Group said:
The Budget provides support for tax reform, a first order national reform issue. We call on the Senate to pass the legislation.
The Business Council of Australia said:
The budget paves the way for tax reform. Australia can now get on with the vital task of building a better, more competitive and fairer tax system.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry stated:
In the end, what this budget has done is prepare the way for the next one which should follow the introduction of a new tax system.
The Australian government has shown the lead. It is now up to the Senate to take advantage of that opportunity. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Youth Allowance

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister explain why the government is prepared to pay her department $366.5 million over four years to implement the GST package but is only prepared to compensate youth allowance victims to the tune of $170 million—less than half that provided for GST related departmental expenses? Isn't this another example of the government's misguided priorities? Why is the government prepared to spend more to implement an unfair tax than it is prepared to spend compensating the families who will bear the brunt of that tax?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Right at the end of the question came the problem for the Labor Party. They describe the money in question as being money used for implementing a tax. What they have not recognised is that it is the money required to support and provide services to Australia's families. There is not only a new tax system but also a new method of delivering tax and family benefits to Australia's families. One of the problems has been that an awful lot of Australia's families who need special help tend to live outside the metropolitan areas where so many Labor Party members come from. The need is to have a wide network of family assistance offices around Australia which provide easy access not only to people's entitlements but also to information and advice about their entitlements and information on services.

answer.para: There are something like 300 Centrelink offices around Australia; there are about 26 tax offices around Australia; and there are over 220 Health Insurance Commission offices around Australia. They will all have a family assistance office presence, which means they can widely cover this vast country of ours, taking services to families where they are and giving them the help they need. One of the things that was learnt from the family tax initiative was that, often, families do not make choices that are in their own best interests when determining whether to take a benefit—

talk.start.para: —How patronising.

—No, it is not; it is helpful. Families have to decide whether it is better for them to take a benefit through the tax system or through the welfare system. I don't want families not getting the maximum entitlement which the law allows them. The lack of advice and information for them is to be overcome by having family assistance offices around Australia. Families will be able to take their new benefits as a lump sum at the end of the year—for some families this will be an attractive option because there will be a sense of enforced saving, which they often want to do but find it difficult under the normal pressures of family life—or they will be able to take them as tax deductions in their pay packet, or they will be able to take them through a payment to the primary carer. It is sometimes complicated for people to assess what is the best measure for them.

answer.para: That is an indication of some of the help that people will get in a family assistance office. It requires a major IT system and it requires the provision of information at that point of contact with people—helpful people. To describe it as the implementation of a tax is to totally misread the purpose of the family assistance officers. Only a party that really does not give a damn about Australia's families, wherever they live, would try and portray it in that way.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain why, aside from these huge GST implementation costs, the government is cutting $12.6 million from family assistance in the year 1999-2000, as indicated on page 86 of Budget Paper No. 2? Why has the minister allowed the Treasurer to put this $12.6 million towards his $5.4 billion surplus, instead of ensuring that they are passed on to those who need them most—that is, the families who will be dependent upon assistance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —That is hardly a supplementary question. It is a new question on a new topic, but I am happy to take it because it is important to make sure the Labor Party does not remain in the ignorance it constantly wallows in. The savings of $12 million to which you referred, Senator, are not family allowance matters; in fact, they are a change in the indexation date—
—It's here on page 86.

—Madam President, does the Senator want to hear my answer or does she want to tell me across the chamber? I do not mind which, but she is in ignorance. Indexation of the child-care assistance will occur in July 2000, along with the introduction of the new child-care benefit, rather than in April 2000. It is an adjustment measure which produces a one-off saving in 1999-2000 of the $12 million referred to.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Last night's federal budget has been widely acclaimed as a family friendly budget with boosts in particular to low and middle income families and families with children. I ask: would the minister please outline the benefits to families announced in the budget?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Crane for the question. While some people might like to live in cloud-cuckoo-land, Senator Crane recognises the reality is that this budget is recognised as being a very important, family friendly budget. I draw the attention of the Senate to one of the budget documents entitled Strengthening and Supporting Australian Families. If people do not want to rely on misinformation from the opposition, I suggest they go to their local member to get a copy of that publication and see for themselves the wide range of measures which have been introduced in this budget and will help Australia's families in one way or another.

answer.para: First and foremost has got to be the major restructuring of the family assistance package and family assistance offices. That is vitally important to the future of Australia's families. Also the lower interest rates have enabled Australia's families to afford a home or better maintain a mortgage without the same stress as was the case under Labor, which presided over 17 per cent interest rates which crippled families as well as sending small businesses into liquidation. Now that we have a budget surplus of $5.4 billion, Australians can square their shoulders and be proud of the fact that they are going forward with greater hope for the future than they have had for many years.

Let me talk about child care because so much misinformation about child care has been put about. Let me make it absolutely clear: the number of child-care places have been increased every year that we have been in government. Money for child care has been increased for every year we have been in government. We are now spending $1.1 billion on child care, which is more than Labor spent when it was in government. There will be $598 million extra for the period 2000 to 2003 through the child-care benefit, and it is better targeted at places that are available for families in areas of highest need. The assistance for families with children in child care will increase by $7.50 per week for a low income family with one child in care paying average fees, by $11 for two children and by $32 for three or more children in care.

Very importantly, and it is badly needed, there will be higher rates of assistance for families with several children in child care, regardless of what type of service they use, and families using part-time care—we know many of the primary carers are also in the work force part time—will be able to get increased assistance of 10 per cent more for up to 33 hours in long day care centres. That is very important practical help for families.

One of the big worries of families is the scourge of drugs and drug addiction in the young. There are over $295 million already committed for the fight against drugs and there was an additional $221 million announced at the last Premiers Conference by the Prime Minister. There will be $60 million going towards preventing chronic youth homelessness, and any parent in Australia would think that would be money well spent. There are increased amounts of money going into building family relationships, better enhancing relationships, and supporting men who are having difficulty so that they can enjoy happier relationships.

Another prevention measure that will help families is another $25 million, making $50 million for preventing domestic violence, preventing harm to our children who witness domestic violence, helping perpetrators stop their own violence, and getting the community to understand that it is a crime and that we must all take action. Madam President, I could go on and on, there are so many pages of assistance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Will the minister confirm that Centrelink will have 5,000 fewer staff to assist customers as a result of this government's funding cuts? Will the minister confirm that last year there were 6.4 million unsuccessful call attempts to Centrelink, and only one in six callers made it through? Does the minister seriously contend that replacing people with answering machines is the answer to the needs of Centrelink clients?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —When we came into government we inherited a call centre system which was utterly decrepit and could not answer the needs of the customers. Ever since, we have put more and more people into call centres. We have spread them around regional Australia so that there are more employment opportunities, and we have put in efficiency measures to try to establish best practice in call centre management. That is all behind us. Now, in this budget, we are introducing two new call centres—one in Maryborough and one in Port Augusta. This was a commitment which we gave in September during the election campaign. We wanted to establish a couple of call centres, each with about 50 people who come from rural areas, who understand rural issues and who would be appropriately helpful to people with problems that need addressing because of their personal circumstances in rural Australia.

answer.para: These are important measures which will be introduced this year. In addition, we are running a pilot project to test the introduction of electronic service delivery, because there is quite often great pressure on the call centre system—maybe after a quarterly letter has gone out or people have had a payday and they are not sure whether their money is in the bank. Those kinds of things cause the peak load to grow in Centrelink. People who can be answered quite quickly make up quite a part of the call centre demand on some days. People will be able to get those sorts of answers in an electronic manner over the call centre system, thus freeing up time for people who have more complex issues to be addressed and who need to speak to an officer. This has been done by a number of businesses, as you would know, Madam President. It is good, efficient management of resources. We are testing it as a pilot to see how Centrelink and the customers can work through it and find a good solution for everybody.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you failed to answer the first part of my question, where I asked about the 6.4 million unsuccessful call attempts to Centrelink last year and the fact that only one in six callers made it through. I ask you to address that. I also ask: is it a fact that, while the tax office is getting an additional 2,100 GST tax police, Centrelink is losing 1,050 staff who are meant to be assisting low income Australians? What does this say about the government's priorities?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I cannot answer as to detail of the callers that actually got through, but that sounds like a grossly exaggerated figure which was being used by the shadow minister. The reason for that is that I get frequent graphs demonstrating the call—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the opposition have got nothing to scoff at. They gave us a call centre system which was hopelessly understaffed, hopelessly inadequate, and we have spent three years trying to get the system we inherited into shape.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—Do you know, Madam President, I do not think they really care about the answer. We have put on something like 400 extra staff in May. As at 10 May, 159 of them are operational; the remainder will be operational by the end of May. There are a number of measures that have been taken, Senator. I would love to tell you. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heri tage, Senator Hill. Last night's budget indicated that government grants that are made to voluntary environment and heritage organisations will be `dependent on whether their activities contribute to government environmental and heritage priorities'. Can the minister give examples of what types of activities by a conservation organisation may be seen as not contributing to the government's environmental priorities?

—It is incredible, Madam President. Senator Bolkus put out a press release raising the same point and criticising the guidelines. Senator Brown—surprise, surprise—put out the same press release criticising them. The Australian Democrats, never to be left out, come in here today and ask a question on the same issue. It must be the biggest issue around in the environment. I will read the guidelines by which I was guided. They state:

answer.para: The current environmental priorities of the Commonwealth government are to be taken into account in determining the funding or level of funding of particular organisations whose activities are directed to those priorities.
I think they are excellent guidelines and that is why I adopted them. They were, of course, the guidelines of Senator Faulkner when he was minister.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can I take it from the minister's answer that making public information which is contrary to government environmental policy decisions is seen as not contributing to your environmental priorities? Isn't this criteria for funding just part of an ongoing campaign to intimidate and silence groups which are the most effective in exposing some of the nastiest decisions your government is responsible for? What is the point of funding community organisations if they are so totally restricted in what they are able to say and do and are forced to become simply underpaid propaganda merchants for the government?
—Community groups seem to be willing to take the approximately $1.7 million that we appropriated for the purpose last year and about the same sum of money that is being appropriated this year.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Is it not a fact that, using the forecast of average wages growth provided in the budget papers, pensioner compensation for the GST will erode within just four years?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —This is a question which has been asked in one form or another for several months, and the fact remains that the impact of the GST will be on prices. Therefore, the compensation is related to the cost of living index, the CPI. We have also introduced another benchmark to protect pensioners from the potential of falling living standards, which is over and above and in addition to the CPI benchmark which has been used for generations. Whatever the cost of living index rises to in the future, pensions will be at 1½ per cent above that index—in other words, above what they would be with today's—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Somehow the Labor Party thinks that because you have a second benchmark—
—Order!
—There are two benchmarks and whichever is the highest is the one which will determine what pensioners receive.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many senators on my left interjecting.
—The income of pensioners will continue to rise by whichever of the benchmarks at any given time is the higher, but their income can never drop below 1½ per cent of CPI. They have full compensation.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Don't these budget paper forecasts indicate that, in the year 2003-04, pensioners would have been getting $426 a fortnight without the GST and in the same year they will be getting a pension worth $426 with the GST? How does the minister justify a compensation package that evaporates so quickly? If the Treasury can admit that the GST compensation erodes to zero, why can't the Minister for Family and Community Services admit it?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —No, they do not.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. I refer to the recent signing of the WA Regional Forest Agreement, and I ask: did the minister support the allocation for logging and woodchipping of those old growth forests such as Dawson, Giblett, Jane, Peak, Rocky and Sharpe which were placed on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate on the recommendation of his own department? If he did support that decision to allow logging in these important areas, on whose advice did he make that decision? If he did not, when did he become aware of this decision?

—The Regional Forest Agreement for Western Australia has been signed, and it is a very significant achievement both for the environment and for industry in Western Australia. As honourable senators know, the Regional Forest Agreement scheme is based on a Commonwealth-state agreement—negotiated by our predecessors, I concede—which was designed to provide for a comprehensive, adequate and representative conservation reserve system whilst at the same time giving resource security for the timber industry. This government has been pleased that it has been able to achieve a number of agreements pursuant to those guidelines—first in Tasmania, two in Victoria, now in Western Australia and we are very close to the first in New South Wales—and by the end of the year we hope to conclude the process.

answer.para: As I said, the Western Australian agreement achieves some very good outcomes for the environment—in particular, the achievement of all reserve criteria targets for all ecosystems where possible on public lands, and the creation of an additional 12 national parks and 25 additions to existing national parks. In total, over 150,000 hectares of new reserves will be added to an already extensive reserve system, representing a net increase of 114,000 hectares over the existing reservation. Two-thirds, or 67 per cent, of all old growth forests in Western Australia will be protected within the reserve system.

talk.start.para: —How many?

—It is 67 per cent of all old growth. The agreement provides for an extensive capture of places on the National Estate interim list—the ones that were not mentioned by the honourable senator—with 82 per cent of those places in the reserve system. Eighty-two per cent are able to be retained, Senator. The agreement delivers a total reserve system of 1,047,000 hectares, over one-third of the native vegetation of the region.
—What about her question?
—I can give you some more examples if you like.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is on answering the question. The minister sounds like he is about to wind up, but he has not actually answered the specific question: on whose advice did he make the change of decision or, if he did not make the decision, when did he become aware of that change? I hope he is going to answer it at some stage.
—I am sure the minister is aware of your question, Senator.

—Madam President, I was just going to remind the honourable senator that, in addition, we are adding high biodiversity areas to the reserve system, such as Wandoo, the Scott River plain and the Darling escarpment adjoining the Blackwood Plateau and the section to the east of Perth. As I have said, in this agreement—which is a balance between the environmental goals and providing resource security for a timber industry that we hope will continue to flourish and provide jobs for Western Australians—we have been able to retain 82 per cent of those places that were on the Register of the National Estate.

—On a point of order, Madam President, the question was not about why the senator has been involved in the protection of areas. It was quite clearly about why the senator has been involved in the destruction of areas, including National Estate areas which have been protected under his own hand. He has not addressed that question, and I ask you to direct him to do so.
—I cannot direct him how to answer a question. There is no point of order. The minister is being relevant to the matter raised.

—I was explaining to the honourable senator, who I assumed was interested in the environmental outcome, what a good environmental outcome had been achieved. In fact, 82 per cent of the places on the interim list were able to be retained within the reserve system. I would have thought that that was a pretty good outcome. I took advice under the EP(IP) Act and the Prime Minister took advice under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, and those advices were obviously taken into account in the outcome.

—I have a supplementary question. I thank the minister in as much as he gave an answer. I know the relevance was that trees were involved in the answer, but it did not actually involve answering the question. Right near the end of the minister's answer, he said, `I took advice,' and by way of a supplementary question I would like him to say advice from whom and when. Can the minister confirm that, whilst the publicity material associated with the signing of the RFA proclaims—and you mentioned this in your answer—that 12 new national parks have been created, 16 already approved national parks, nature reserves and conservation reserves have either been revoked or gutted under the RFA and that 54,000 hectares of forest that were approved by government to become conservation reserves have had their conservation status revoked? On whose advice and when, Minister, did you make that decision?

—I actually do not sign the agreement but I give advice in the process of reaching the agreement. We did, as I said, take into account all matters to determine a good environmental outcome and a good job security outcome. It is interesting to note that most of the Western Australian press that I have seen on the RFA outcome has been particularly positive. If you look at just one side of the ledger, you will always find something to carp about but, if you look at both sides and you want a good jobs outcome and a good environment outcome, when you look at the WA RFA you will think a pretty fair job has been done.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Family and Community Services: Release of Budget Details

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Has the minister received her late night report on how significant budget details were made public on her departmental web site hours before the Treasurer's speech? Can she confirm that this embarrassing revelation came about because the operation of the departmental web site has recently been outsourced to a private IT firm who had no knowledge of the need to protect the security of sensitive budget details? Can the minister also confirm that this outsourcing resulted in the departmental web site being inaccessible for at least the last 12 days, only coming online to drop the budget announcements? Just who has the minister decided to blame this time for the latest embarrassment within her own portfolio and ministerial responsibilities?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It was actually Labor that outsourced ITs. It was the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Do you remember, Senator? I acknowledge that budget media releases were put on my web site yesterday afternoon. The secretary to the department has acknowledged that it was a departmental error. He has undertaken to ensure a thorough formal investigation of the circumstances which led to the serious breach of budget confidentiality. I expect a full explanation, an analysis of any deficiencies in departmental procedures and controls, and consideration of appropriate corrective and disciplinary measures. The preliminary report of the department's investigation last night has come across and it indicates that the release occurred as the result of a series of technical and human errors associated with preparation to meet the requirement for budget information on government web sites immediately following the budget speech.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Given that the minister does not even understand who was responsible for outsourcing IT in the Department of Social Security and, therefore, the Department of Family and Community Services—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. We have had about 15 or 20 seconds of abusive introduction. There is not a skerrick of a question contained in that proposition, and I suggest that you rule Senator Faulkner out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam President: apart from the dishonesty and the inaccuracy in the statement that Senator Alston made, I would draw your attention to the sort of preamble that government senators—for example, Senator Crane—used in their questions in question time today and I would ask you to rule Senator Alston's non-point of order out of order.

—It has become a custom for preambles to questions—which probably should be a great deal shorter than they are—that they should not be abusive. The level of sledging that has been going on in the chamber in recent times is unacceptable. I ask Senator Faulkner to ask his question.

—Is the minister aware that all participants in the budget lock-up had to sign secrecy agreements before entering the room and that a breach of those requirements would have been a breach of the Commonwealth Crimes Act? I ask whether she is also aware that the Deutsche Bank summary of the budget led with the line:

question.para: The greatest excitement generated by the 1999-2000 Commonwealth budget was the accidental release of a number of press statements relating to budget initiatives by the Family and Community Services ministry.

Given how serious this issue is, why don't you for once take full responsibility yourself for this serious lapse of security within your own portfolio—as opposed to pointing the finger, as you always do, at someone else?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women
