Despite the proven benefits of non-union workplaces, and despite all Mr Carr's protestations about wanting to change Labor's ethos, the bitter reality is that the New South Wales Labor government is dominated by the unions and that the government is therefore simply unable to resist their demands.

The unions control in the vicinity of 60 per cent of the vote at Labor Party conferences. They control who gets preselection and in what position, and they control what policies go forward and what gets held back. The unions in New South Wales are, in effect, the invisible hand that controls the government. Mr Carr has been forced to acknowledge that his desire and that of his Treasurer, Mr Egan, to privatise electricity in New South Wales was opposed by the unions and he had to give in. Now it appears that Mr Carr and his Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Shaw—whose preselection in a winnable upper house spot required decisive intervention—have been called on to pay back the unions for support and funds for the March election. And pay back, big time, they have—by entertaining these proposals.

These measures represent some of the most regressive industrial relations proposals, either state or federal, this country has seen in a decade. But the New South Wales government's preparedness to do the unions' bidding has both sinister and frightening implications for the people of New South Wales. First, it means Labor is governing for its union mates—a small, elite special interest group—and not in the best interests of the people of New South Wales. Secondly, these proposals are opportunistic. Labor has no mandate to do this, having failed to tell the people of New South Wales just weeks ago during the election campaign that this was in store for them as soon as the government was safely returned.

The proposals will weaken the rights of small business, especially in the building industry and other industries where union coercion of contractors and non-union employees has been a feature. In my view, state and federal ALP members in New South Wales whose parliamentary careers rely on the votes and support of union officials and who will benefit from these proposals have a clear obligation to all of their constituents, not just to their supporters, to tell them about the real effects of these proposals.

Increasing union power to intrude into established employer-employee relationships is bad for jobs and economic growth. It intrudes on the rights of ordinary workers. This is when Australia is only now starting to do better in workplace relations because of the deregulatory IR changes focusing on the workplace started by the New South Wales Greiner and Fahey coalition governments and adopted since then, I must say, by state and federal governments of both political persuasions throughout the country.

The New South Wales proposals contrast dramatically with the approach of the federal coalition, which also issued an implementation paper on its second term industrial relations proposals in early May. Those proposals were line by line in accordance with our election policy, and the proposals were spelt out side by side. The federal coalition policy is to promote cooperative workplace relations respecting the rights of all employees, union and non-union alike.

The New South Wales Employers Federation Chief Executive, Garry Brack, has described these proposals as `a kind of insanity' and as an `anti-business package'. Although there has been a suggestion that the government will listen to the concerns of business and unions about the proposals, I certainly hope it is not a done deal. I hope I am wrong about this and I also hope that the public outrage that will accompany any attempt to ram these proposals through will give the Carr government the intestinal fortitude to do the right thing for the majority of the people in New South Wales. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Parliament House: Electronic Access to Budget Documents
Information Technology: Equity of Access

talk.start.para: —It is interesting on this day following budget day that one of the focuses of many of the minds in Parliament House has not been on analysing what is going on with respect to the budget. Why? Because we have not been able to get access to many of those documents. Today in Parliament House we witnessed an absolute disaster in terms of using information technology. I watch with interest, as these difficulties become more apparent in the wider community, whom the government will seek to blame. We saw today in the chamber a very rapid sideways shift of responsibility from Minister Newman with respect to an IT blunder within her own department. Many people in Parliament House had great difficulty today in accessing their exchange server services as well as the actual budget documents, and I am looking to see where the blame will be shifted to.

speech.para: By way of general comment, I point out that it is an issue that is budget related. The services in Parliament House need to be fully funded to the level necessary to deliver what we require and, in analogous terms, to the level of information technology that any general business, commercial, government, or community-based operation would deserve and expect. If you want to have a quality system you must be prepared to fund it to the degree necessary.

Over the last three years we have seen the exemplary services provided by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office being put under great pressure by this government in its willingness to cut back, not to mention the attacks on morale with the continual rumours of outsourcing circulating within that office. Indeed, many senators opposite will know my intense interest in the government's IT outsourcing process and how that process attacks generally the whole notion of control and strategic management of what I believe to be a core issue for any business, community organisation or government. We are dealing with information technology in an age when it is not something you can hang off the side of an operation. Here in Parliament House we have seen that really come to fruition.

Information is the business of all of us. As politicians, information is the fuel upon which we sustain ourselves each working day. To find that our information systems do not work does undermine our ability to actually do our work. What we experienced today was that the budget papers were not fully loaded onto the internal parliamentary information system and a great load was imposed upon that system as just about everyone in the building tried to access the documents for the first time electronically. What should have been quite a glorious day celebrating the wonders of information technology in this place actually degenerated to a point where hardly anybody could use their information access systems, their computers. Rather, documents were damaged as Parliament House staff tried to open them, and delays of many minutes in just doing simple tasks like opening emails occurred. In fact it is the first time since I have been elected that I have actually experienced such a horrendous delay and breakdown in those services.

I can only suggest that it is because of inadequate investment in the systems in the first instance. There is evidence of this in the delay by the Department of Finance and Administration in funding Internet access in the first instance. For quite a long time in the early period of the coalition government, all members of parliament awaited eagerly the ability to access the Internet, only to find that the funding could not be found. This was eventually changed at some latter point and Internet access was rolled out within Parliament House and efforts were made to roll it out to electorate offices.

It is worthy of note that when the Internet roll-out program was first initiated it included the electorate offices of parliamentarians. However, when it came to the crunch, the part of the information technology that was the responsibility of the then Department of Administrative Services was outsourced to CSC, and that vendor did not carry on the program of rolling out Internet access to electorate offices. Indeed, we are now at the point where this program has not been completed, despite many members of parliament thinking that that would be the case over time. This is something that needs to be followed up.

Let me go back to parliament today coming to a virtual standstill in electronic terms. For someone who relies quite heavily on email this caused a great disruption. In analysing the situation, it seems that DOFA contributed significantly to the problem when it several times mailed a bulk email relating to agreements being negotiated in this place—hence, exacerbating the problem. I would expect anyone who claims to have some understanding and financial control over an information system to have some sensitivity as to the capability of it, but that is not the case. It will be interesting to see where exactly the government seeks to place the blame for this matter.

I want to finish my comments tonight by saying a few general things about information technology and Internet access. The fact that we have a sophisticated—indeed, cutting edge—information technology system here in Parliament House means that we are privileged and distinct from the majority Australians. The fact that we have Internet access puts us in that small category of the 20 per cent of Australians who have Internet access. In our case, it is afforded to us by virtue of taxpayers' money. We think it is imperative to be connected in this way and to have these services—I know it facilitates my ability to do my job properly—so it is not unreasonable to expect that anyone in the community or in business should have that same advantage.

The question of equity of access to information technologies and the Internet becomes, I suppose, the focus of my comments this evening. We experienced today what happens when the system goes down and you lose that access. More than anything else, the message in this is that information technology, no matter where you are, is core business. It is fundamental to the way we operate and the way in which we communicate and interact with others. The 80 per cent of the population who currently do not have Internet access are isolated in the same way that we were isolated today when the system did not work.

For governments, the message behind this is very plain: look at how you work and look at how you use the information technology and the Internet. Look at what happens when it goes down; imagine if you did not have it. It is a different way of living. I firmly believe that all Australians should be able to enjoy the opportunity to participate fully in the information society. I believe all Australians should have the capability and the skills to choose whether they want to participate in the information society, and they should be able to do so with confidence.

This requires a far broader policy agenda from this government than just a narrowband information economy approach that looks at the dollar figures and the economic outcomes and forgets about the profound social implications that arise out of these new technologies—more than implications: real opportunities for people, whether they be in isolated areas for remote rural access or in schools, with all the educational opportunities that are there for young Australians.

It was a telling day for many parliamentarians as to how much we take for granted. I hope within that experience today there lies a powerful policy message—that all Australians should be afforded the opportunity to participate in the information society.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Office of Government Information and Advertising
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 286)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the Government's position regarding Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA) officials acting as formal referees for firms tendering for Commonwealth research work.

(2) Was Mr Borko Vlatkovic, Director Research and Ministerial (OGIA), involved in: (a) the compilation of the short list of companies invited to tender for the market research associated with the community education and information program; and (b) any aspect of OGIA's work in support of the market research work associated with the community education and information campaign.
(3) Did any other OGIA personnel act as referees for firms invited to tender for work associated with the program.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I am advised that OGIA officials did not—and Government Communications Unit (GCU) officials do not—encourage firms tendering for government work to nominate them as referees. Although the practice is discouraged, it is not unknown for firms to nominate OGIA/GCU officials as referees when drawing attention to past government work as part of their proposals for future government work.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 30 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What guidelines or restrictions will there be governing how winning schools are able to spend prize money.
(2) Will schools be permitted to spend prize monies on a purpose unrelated to literacy and numeracy as long as the project has educational merit.
(3) Can a list, by name, be provided of members of the assessment panel; if this has not been finalised, what is its likely composition and what organisations will be represented.
(4) What criteria will be used in judging schools eligible for cash prizes.
(5) Were there any other ways explored to encourage literacy achievement with the $160,000 that will now be used for cash prizes; if so, can details be provided.
(6) Did the Government consult any literacy assessors, researchers or specialists in formulating the idea of a cash prize.
(7) Was there any assessment made regarding whether the prize would have any beneficial effect on literacy and numeracy outcomes.
(8) Is the prize expected to translate directly into an improvement in outcomes; if so how.
(9) Can the Minister explain how these cash prizes will assist children with learning difficulties, learning disabilities and behavioural problems impeding literacy acquisition.
(10) How will these cash prizes assist teachers in detecting literacy difficulties in students.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Award-winning schools are required to use their prize money for a range of school-based strategies and activities that will support further improvements in literacy and numeracy. A copy of the guidelines is at Attachment A.
(2) No, schools will not be permitted to spend prize monies on purchases unrelated to literacy and numeracy.

(3) State selection committees with representation from the non-government sector and the Commonwealth will be established to nominate primary schools that fulfil the award criteria (see Attachment B). Lists of names of selection committee members have not yet been provided to DETYA. The Department expects to receive this information when it receives State and Territory submissions for National Literacy Week funding. These are due on 23 April 1999.
(4) The award criteria for judging schools eligible for the National Literacy Week Awards for Literacy and Numeracy Achievement are at Attachment B.

(5) In 1998, the Government set aside $1 million to support a range of public awareness activities during National Literacy Week which is to be established for the first time in 1999. In order to give it a high profile, the Government decided that National Literacy Week needed an innovative focus that would distinguish it from existing events such as Book Week. Subsequently, the Minister approved the allocation of up to $200,000 to fund the awards and associated promotion activities so that the event would have a strong national focus and involve primary schools, parents and local community groups.

(6) The National Literacy Week initiative is being developed by a Commonwealth/ State Working Group, which met for the first time on 1 February 1999. It includes one representative from each State and Territory and is chaired by Dr Evan Arthur, Assistant Secretary, Literacy and Special Programs Branch. All Working Group members support the idea for the awards. A list of members is at Attachment C.

(7) National Literacy Week awards will go to schools that have added significantly to students' literacy and numeracy performance, not just to those scoring highest in literacy and numeracy. They will recognise that schools will have different starting points in terms of student outcomes. As noted in the answer to Question 1, award-winning schools will be able to use their prize money for a range of school-based strategies and activities that will support further improvements in literacy and numeracy.

(8) The awards are expected to raise public awareness of the importance of all Australian students developing effective literacy and numeracy skills, and to recognise and reward schools that are contributing to significant improvements in literacy and numeracy outcomes.

(9) The awards will have an equity focus. They will go to schools that have improved the performance of their students, recognising that schools will have different starting points in terms of literacy and numeracy outcomes. For schools with educationally disadvantaged students, improvements in outright performance will be more difficult to achieve. This approach to awarding the cash prizes will help these schools gain the recognition and sense of achievement they need, and to support improvements against their previous best.

(10) The awards are aimed at rewarding and publicly recognising schools that are progressing the implementation of the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan and supporting attainment of the national literacy and numeracy goals. The Plan is directed at early identification of students who are having literacy learning difficulties, and intervention to address their needs.
Attachment A
USE OF FUNDS
Funds awarded to schools may be used for a range of school-based strategies and activities that will support further improvements in students' literacy and numeracy outcomes, and may include:
* salaries for teachers, specialists and support staff;
* development of programs that directly assist students, including:
. preparing, publishing or purchasing and implementing program/curriculum/professional development/assessment materials that can be used to support improved student literacy and numeracy outcomes;
. computer assisted and other specialised learning techniques; or
. items of equipment such as computers or teaching aids.
* support and training for volunteer literacy and numeracy program tutors;
* employment of literacy or numeracy co-ordinators, advisory staff, interpreters, translators, welfare officers including bilingual officers, teachers' aides and school-community liaison workers;
* trialling, evaluating, disseminating and delivering professional development material; and
* teacher and support inservice opportunities.
Attachment B
NATIONAL LITERACY WEEK AWARDS FOR LITERACY AND NUMERACY ACHIEVEMENT—AWARDS CRITERIA

The emphasis of the National Literacy Week Awards will be on recognising and rewarding innovative practice leading to value-added improvements in student literacy or numeracy performance. States/Territories are invited to nominate government and non-government primary schools that have shown improvement in literacy and/or numeracy through best practice.
The Awards will have a strong equity focus, and will recognise that schools will have different starting points in terms of students' literacy and numeracy outcomes.
To be eligible for a National Literacy Week Award for Literacy and Numeracy Achievement, government and non-government primary schools must fulfil the following criteria.

* Nominated schools must demonstrate that they are progressing the implementation of the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan and supporting attainment of the national literacy and numeracy goals. In particular, nominated schools must demonstrate that they are implementing effective literacy/numeracy instructional programs that have value-added to students' performance. By "value-added", it is meant that a school's teaching programs have significantly improved students' literacy/numeracy performance, given those students' starting point.

Nominations should be accompanied by evidence that focuses on improvement against baseline data on educational outcomes in literacy and numeracy. State and Territory selection committees may provide either school level, or system-based, outcomes data to support their identification of schools that are achieving improvements through intervention.

It is acknowledged that many non-government school education authorities are in the initial stages of implementing the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan (which commenced in 1998). In future years, validated data such as that becoming available from the national benchmarking process should be used to demonstrate evidence of improved performance by schools and improved literacy levels of students.
Attachment C
COMMONWEALTH/STATE NATIONAL LITERACY WEEK WORKING GROUP
Dr Evan Arthur (Chair), Assistant Secretary, Literacy and Special Programs Branch, Schools Division, DETYA
Mr Lindsay Wasson, Director of Curriculum Support, NSW Department of Education & Training
Mr Ross Kimber, Assistant General Manager, Curriculum Development & Learning, Technologies Branch, Education Victoria
Mr Tony Cook, Manager, Literacy and Numeracy Unit, Education Queensland
Ms Diana Rees, Project Leader, Literacy, Education Department of WA
Ms Gerry Mulhearn, Curriculum Superintendent, SA Department of Education, Training & Employment
Ms Alison Jacob, Director of Planning, Executive Support Branch, Department of Education, Training, Community & Cultural Development
Ms Connie Emslie, Acting Manager, NT Literacy Plan, NT Department of Education
Mr Allan Hird, Director, School Programs Branch, ACT Department of Education and Community Services

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 April 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister reviewed, or will the Minister review, his decision to give an export licence to a Tasmanian abattoir for sending wild brush-tail possum carcasses overseas; if so: (a) when; and (b) what studies have been, or will be done, for that review; if no review is planned, why not.
(2) How many carcasses have been exported.
(3) Have any measures been undertaken to ensure that no inhumane treatment of the possums occurs: (a) in the field; (b) in transport; or (c) in the abattoir; if so, what are those measures.
(4) Are Tasmanian possums being sold in Taiwan, Hong Kong or elsewhere, as `Australian Tree Foxes' or any other fake appellation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The export of brush-tail possum carcasses from Tasmania is subject to three separate decisions under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 (the Act). Firstly, approval of a Management Program under subsection 10(1) of the Act; secondly, the approval of an annual quota; and thirdly, the issuing of an export permit on each occasion that carcasses are to be exported.

On 12 December 1996 I approved the Management Program entitled `Management Program for the brush-tail possum Trichosurus vulpecula (Kerr) in Tasmania 1997-1999' submitted by the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service. My approval of this Management Program expires on 31 December 1999.

It will be open to the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service to submit a new plan of management for the species when the current plan expires. Any new plan will be reviewed to ensure it meets the requirements of sections 9B and 10 of the Act and Regulation 5 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Regulations prior to my consideration of the plan.

Under the current Management Program an annual quota of possums that may be shot or trapped for damage mitigation purposes, is established. The quota is established on the basis of the population status of brush-tail possums in Tasmania, trends in the abundance of brush-tail possums, seasonal conditions, and the need for crop protection. The approved quota for the period 1 July 1998 to 30 June 1999 is 250,000.
In view of the information provided above, I do not consider any further review of these decisions is necessary at this time.

(2) My Department does not keep records of the number of carcasses exported unless that is the unit of export. The following information has been extracted from the annual report on the harvest, provided to my Department by the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service, and on the volume of exports, as recorded by my Department:

(3) The capture, transport and slaughter of the brush-tail possums to be exported as carcasses is subject to the Code of Practice for Capture, Handling, Transport and Slaughter of Brush Possums (Tichosurus vulpecula), revised December 1997. This code was endorsed by the Tasmanian Animal Welfare Advisory Committee on 12 December 1997.
(4) My Department does not have information on the trade names used for brush-tail possums in other countries.
